# Crate poemCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/src/poem/lib.rs.html#1-311)
Expand description
Poem is a full-featured and easy-to-use web framework with the Rust programming language.
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#table-of-contents)Table of contents
  * [Quickstart](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#quickstart)
  * [Endpoint](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#endpoint)
  * [Extractors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#extractors)
  * [Routing](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#routing)
  * [Responses](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#responses)
  * [Handling errors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#handling-errors)
  * [Middleware](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#middleware)
  * [Crate features](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#crate-features)


## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#quickstart)Quickstart
```
use poem::{IntoResponse, Route, Server, get, handler, listener::TcpListener, web::Path};
#[handler]
fn hello(Path(name): Path<String>) -> String {
  format!("hello: {}", name)
}
#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), std::io::Error> {
  let app = Route::new().at("/hello/:name", get(hello));
  Server::new(TcpListener::bind("0.0.0.0:3000"))
    .run(app)
    .await
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#endpoint)Endpoint
The [`Endpoint`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint") trait represents a type that can handle HTTP requests, and it returns the `Result<T: IntoResponse, Error>` type.
The [`handler`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/attr.handler.html "attr poem::handler") macro is used to convert a function into an endpoint.
```
use poem::{
  Endpoint, Request, Result, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  test::TestClient,
};
#[handler]
fn return_str() -> &'static str {
  "hello"
}
#[handler]
fn return_err() -> Result<&'static str, NotFoundError> {
  Err(NotFoundError)
}
let resp = TestClient::new(return_str).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status_is_ok();
resp.assert_text("hello").await;
let resp = TestClient::new(return_err).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND);
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#extractors)Extractors
The extractor is used to extract something from the HTTP request.
`Poem` provides some [commonly used extractors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest") for extracting something from HTTP requests.
In the following example, the `index` function uses 3 extractors to extract the remote address, HTTP method and URI.
```
use poem::{
  handler,
  http::{Method, Uri},
  web::RemoteAddr,
};
#[handler]
fn index(remote_addr: &RemoteAddr, method: Method, uri: &Uri) {}
```

By default, the extractor will return a `400 Bad Request` when an error occurs, but sometimes you may want to change this behavior, so you can handle the error yourself.
In the following example, when the [`Query`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/struct.Query.html "struct poem::web::Query") extractor fails, it will return a `500 Internal Server` response and the reason for the error.
```
use poem::{
  IntoResponse, Response, Result, error::ParseQueryError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  web::Query,
};
use serde::Deserialize;
#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
struct Params {
  name: String,
}
#[handler]
fn index(res: Result<Query<Params>>) -> Result<impl IntoResponse> {
  match res {
    Ok(Query(params)) => Ok(params.name.into_response()),
    Err(err) if err.is::<ParseQueryError>() => Ok(Response::builder()
      .status(StatusCode::INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)
      .body(err.to_string())),
    Err(err) => Err(err),
  }
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#routing)Routing
There are three available routes.
  * [`Route`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Route.html "struct poem::Route") Routing for path
  * [`RouteDomain`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteDomain.html "struct poem::RouteDomain") Routing for domain
  * [`RouteMethod`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteMethod.html "struct poem::RouteMethod") Routing for HTTP method


```
use poem::{Route, get, handler, post, web::Path};
#[handler]
async fn get_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn delete_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn create_user() {}
let app = Route::new()
  .at("/user/:id", get(get_user).delete(delete_user))
  .at("/user", post(create_user));
```

You can create custom extractors, see also [`FromRequest`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest").
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#responses)Responses
All types that can be converted to HTTP response [`Response`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Response.html "struct poem::Response") should implement [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse").
In the following example, the `string_response` and `status_response` functions return the `String` and `StatusCode` types, because `Poem` has implemented the [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse") trait for them.
The `no_response` function does not return a value. We can think that its return type is `()`, and `Poem` also implements [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse") for `()`, which is always converted to `200 OK`.
The `result_response` function returns a `Result` type, which means that an error may occur.
```
use poem::{Result, handler, http::StatusCode};
#[handler]
fn string_response() -> String {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn status_response() -> StatusCode {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn no_response() {}
#[handler]
fn result_response() -> Result<String> {
  todo!()
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#handling-errors)Handling errors
The following example returns customized content when [`NotFoundError`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/error/struct.NotFoundError.html "struct poem::error::NotFoundError") occurs.
```
use poem::{
  EndpointExt, IntoResponse, Response, Route, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
};
#[handler]
fn foo() {}
#[handler]
fn bar() {}
let app =
  Route::new()
    .at("/foo", foo)
    .at("/bar", bar)
    .catch_error(|err: NotFoundError| async move {
      Response::builder()
        .status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND)
        .body("custom not found")
    });
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#middleware)Middleware
You can call the [`with`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.EndpointExt.html#method.with "method poem::endpoint::EndpointExt::with") method on the [`Endpoint`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint") to apply a middleware to an endpoint. It actually converts the original endpoint to a new endpoint.
```
use poem::{EndpointExt, Route, handler, middleware::Tracing};
#[handler]
fn index() {}
let app = Route::new().at("/", index).with(Tracing);
```

You can create your own middleware, see also [`Middleware`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/middleware/trait.Middleware.html "trait poem::middleware::Middleware").
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#crate-features)Crate features
To avoid compiling unused dependencies, `Poem` gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:
Feature| Description  
---|---  
server| Server and listener APIs(enable by default)  
compression| Support decompress request body and compress response body  
cookie| Support for Cookie  
csrf| Support for Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) protection  
multipart| Support for Multipart  
native-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`native-tls`](https://crates.io/crates/native-tls)  
openssl-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`openssl-tls`](https://crates.io/crates/openssl)  
opentelemetry| Support for opentelemetry  
prometheus| Support for Prometheus  
redis-session| Support for RedisSession  
rustls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`rustls`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls)  
session| Support for session  
sse| Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
tempfile| Support for [`tempfile`](https://crates.io/crates/tempfile)  
test| Test utilities to test your endpoints.  
tower-compat| Adapters for `tower::Layer` and `tower::Service`.  
websocket| Support for WebSocket  
anyhow| Integrate with the [`anyhow`](https://crates.io/crates/anyhow) crate.  
eyre06| Integrate with version 0.6.x of the [`eyre`](https://crates.io/crates/eyre) crate.  
i18n| Support for internationalization  
acme-native-roots| Support for ACME(Automatic Certificate Management Environment)  
acme-webpki-roots| Support for ACME using webpki TLS roots rather than native TLS roots  
tokio-metrics| Integrate with the [`tokio-metrics`](https://crates.io/crates/tokio-metrics) crate.  
embed| Integrate with [`rust-embed`](https://crates.io/crates/rust-embed) crate.  
xml| Integrate with [`quick-xml`](https://crates.io/crates/quick-xml) crate.  
yaml| Integrate with [`serde-yaml`](https://crates.io/crates/serde-yaml) crate.  
sonic-rs| Uses [`sonic-rs`](https://github.com/cloudwego/sonic-rs) instead of `serde_json`. Pls, checkout `sonic-rs` requirements to properly enable `sonic-rs` capabilities  
## Re-exports[§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#reexports)

`pub use endpoint::Endpoint[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint");`


`pub use endpoint::EndpointExt[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.EndpointExt.html "trait poem::endpoint::EndpointExt");`


`pub use endpoint::IntoEndpoint[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.IntoEndpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::IntoEndpoint");`


`pub use error::Error[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/error/struct.Error.html "struct poem::error::Error");`


`pub use error::Result[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/error/type.Result.html "type poem::error::Result");`


`pub use middleware::Middleware[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/middleware/trait.Middleware.html "trait poem::middleware::Middleware");`


`pub use web::FromRequest[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest");`


`pub use web::IntoResponse[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse");`


`pub use web::RequestBody[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/struct.RequestBody.html "struct poem::web::RequestBody");`

## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#modules)

[endpoint](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/index.html "mod poem::endpoint")
    Endpoint related types.

[error](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/error/index.html "mod poem::error")
    Some common error types.

[http](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/http/index.html "mod poem::http")
    A general purpose library of common HTTP types

[i18n](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/i18n/index.html "mod poem::i18n")`i18n`
    Internationalization related types.

[listener](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/listener/index.html "mod poem::listener")`server`
    Commonly used listeners.

[middleware](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/middleware/index.html "mod poem::middleware")
    Commonly used middleware.

[session](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/session/index.html "mod poem::session")`session`
    Session management.

[test](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/test/index.html "mod poem::test")`test`
    Test utilities to test your endpoints.

[web](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/index.html "mod poem::web")
    Commonly used as the type of extractor or response.
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#structs)

[Body](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Body.html "struct poem::Body")
    A body object for requests and responses.

[OnUpgrade](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.OnUpgrade.html "struct poem::OnUpgrade")
    A future for a possible HTTP upgrade.

    Container that can be used to obtain path pattern from the request.

    Represents an HTTP request.

    An request builder.

    Component parts of an HTTP Request.

[Response](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Response.html "struct poem::Response")
    Represents an HTTP response.

    An response builder.

    Component parts of an HTTP Response.

[Route](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Route.html "struct poem::Route")
    Routing object

[RouteDomain](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteDomain.html "struct poem::RouteDomain")
    Routing object for `HOST` header

[RouteMethod](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteMethod.html "struct poem::RouteMethod")
    Routing object for HTTP methods

[RouteScheme](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteScheme.html "struct poem::RouteScheme")
    Routing object for request scheme

[Server](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Server.html "struct poem::Server")
    An HTTP Server.

[Upgraded](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Upgraded.html "struct poem::Upgraded")
    An upgraded HTTP connection.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#enums)

[Addr](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/enum.Addr.html "enum poem::Addr")

## §⟨5⟩Quickstart
```
use poem::{IntoResponse, Route, Server, get, handler, listener::TcpListener, web::Path};
#[handler]
fn hello(Path(name): Path<String>) -> String {
  format!("hello: {}", name)
}
#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), std::io::Error> {
  let app = Route::new().at("/hello/:name", get(hello));
  Server::new(TcpListener::bind("0.0.0.0:3000"))
    .run(app)
    .await
}
```

## §⟨6⟩Endpoint
The `Endpoint`⟨13⟩ trait represents a type that can handle HTTP requests, and it returns the `Result<T: IntoResponse, Error>` type.
The `handler`⟨14⟩ macro is used to convert a function into an endpoint.
```
use poem::{
  Endpoint, Request, Result, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  test::TestClient,
};
#[handler]
fn return_str() -> &'static str {
  "hello"
}
#[handler]
fn return_err() -> Result<&'static str, NotFoundError> {
  Err(NotFoundError)
}
let resp = TestClient::new(return_str).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status_is_ok();
resp.assert_text("hello").await;
let resp = TestClient::new(return_err).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND);
```

## §⟨7⟩Extractors
The extractor is used to extract something from the HTTP request.
`Poem` provides some commonly used extractors⟨15⟩ for extracting something from HTTP requests.
In the following example, the `index` function uses 3 extractors to extract the remote address, HTTP method and URI.
```
use poem::{
  handler,
  http::{Method, Uri},
  web::RemoteAddr,
};
#[handler]
fn index(remote_addr: &RemoteAddr, method: Method, uri: &Uri) {}
```

By default, the extractor will return a `400 Bad Request` when an error occurs, but sometimes you may want to change this behavior, so you can handle the error yourself.
In the following example, when the `Query`⟨16⟩ extractor fails, it will return a `500 Internal Server` response and the reason for the error.
```
use poem::{
  IntoResponse, Response, Result, error::ParseQueryError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  web::Query,
};
use serde::Deserialize;
#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
struct Params {
  name: String,
}
#[handler]
fn index(res: Result<Query<Params>>) -> Result<impl IntoResponse> {
  match res {
    Ok(Query(params)) => Ok(params.name.into_response()),
    Err(err) if err.is::<ParseQueryError>() => Ok(Response::builder()
      .status(StatusCode::INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)
      .body(err.to_string())),
    Err(err) => Err(err),
  }
}
```

## §⟨8⟩Routing
There are three available routes.
  * `Route`⟨17⟩ Routing for path
  * `RouteDomain`⟨18⟩ Routing for domain
  * `RouteMethod`⟨19⟩ Routing for HTTP method


```
use poem::{Route, get, handler, post, web::Path};
#[handler]
async fn get_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn delete_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn create_user() {}
let app = Route::new()
  .at("/user/:id", get(get_user).delete(delete_user))
  .at("/user", post(create_user));
```

You can create custom extractors, see also `FromRequest`⟨15⟩.
## §⟨9⟩Responses
All types that can be converted to HTTP response `Response`⟨20⟩ should implement `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩.
In the following example, the `string_response` and `status_response` functions return the `String` and `StatusCode` types, because `Poem` has implemented the `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩ trait for them.
The `no_response` function does not return a value. We can think that its return type is `()`, and `Poem` also implements `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩ for `()`, which is always converted to `200 OK`.
The `result_response` function returns a `Result` type, which means that an error may occur.
```
use poem::{Result, handler, http::StatusCode};
#[handler]
fn string_response() -> String {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn status_response() -> StatusCode {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn no_response() {}
#[handler]
fn result_response() -> Result<String> {
  todo!()
}
```

## §⟨10⟩Handling errors
The following example returns customized content when `NotFoundError`⟨22⟩ occurs.
```
use poem::{
  EndpointExt, IntoResponse, Response, Route, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
};
#[handler]
fn foo() {}
#[handler]
fn bar() {}
let app =
  Route::new()
    .at("/foo", foo)
    .at("/bar", bar)
    .catch_error(|err: NotFoundError| async move {
      Response::builder()
        .status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND)
        .body("custom not found")
    });
```

## §⟨11⟩Middleware
You can call the `with`⟨23⟩ method on the `Endpoint`⟨13⟩ to apply a middleware to an endpoint. It actually converts the original endpoint to a new endpoint.
```
use poem::{EndpointExt, Route, handler, middleware::Tracing};
#[handler]
fn index() {}
let app = Route::new().at("/", index).with(Tracing);
```

You can create your own middleware, see also `Middleware`⟨24⟩.

To avoid compiling unused dependencies, `Poem` gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:

sse| Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
tempfile| Support for `tempfile`⟨28⟩  
test| Test utilities to test your endpoints.

websocket| Support for WebSocket  
anyhow| Integrate with the `anyhow`⟨29⟩ crate.  
eyre06| Integrate with version 0.6.x of the `eyre`⟨30⟩ crate.  
i18n| Support for internationalization

# Poem Framework
[ ![Crates.io version](https://img.shields.io/crates/v/poem.svg?style=flat-square) ](https://crates.io/crates/poem) [ ![Download](https://img.shields.io/crates/d/poem.svg?style=flat-square) ](https://crates.io/crates/poem) [ ![docs.rs docs](https://img.shields.io/badge/docs-latest-blue.svg?style=flat-square) ](https://docs.rs/poem) [ ![Unsafe Rust forbidden](https://img.shields.io/badge/unsafe-forbidden-success.svg?style=flat-square) ](https://github.com/rust-secure-code/safety-dance/) ![rustc 1.85.0+](https://img.shields.io/badge/rustc-1.85.0+-ab6000.svg) [ ![](https://img.shields.io/discord/932986985604333638.svg?label=&logo=discord&logoColor=ffffff&color=7389D8&labelColor=6A7EC2) ](https://discord.gg/qWWNxwasb7)
``A program is like a poem`,` you cannot write a poem without writing it`.` `-``-``-` Dijkstra``
A full-featured and easy-to-use web framework with the Rust programming language.
  * [Docs](https://docs.rs/poem)
  * [Cargo package](https://crates.io/crates/poem)


## Features
  * Both _Ease_ of use and performance.
  * Minimizing the use of generics.
  * Blazing fast and flexible routing.
  * ```tower`::``Service`` and ```tower`::``Layer`` compatibility.
  * Use [poem-openapi](https://lib.rs/crates/poem-openapi) to write APIs that comply with [OAS3](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification) specifications and automatically generate documents.


## Crate features
To avoid compiling unused dependencies, Poem gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:
Feature | Description  
---|---  
server | Server and listener APIs (enabled by default)  
compression | Support decompress request body and compress response body  
cookie | Support for Cookie  
csrf | Support for Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) protection  
multipart | Support for Multipart  
native-tls | Support for HTTP server over TLS with [``native-tls``](https://lib.rs/crates/native-tls)  
openssl-tls | Support for HTTP server over TLS with [``openssl-tls``](https://lib.rs/crates/openssl)  
opentelemetry | Support for opentelemetry  
prometheus | Support for Prometheus  
redis-session | Support for RedisSession  
rustls | Support for HTTP server over TLS with [``rustls``](https://lib.rs/crates/rustls)  
session | Support for session  
sse | Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
static-files | Support static files endpoint  
tempfile | Support for [``tempfile``](https://lib.rs/crates/tempfile)  
tower-compat | Adapters for ```tower`::``Layer`` and ```tower`::``Service``.  
websocket | Support for WebSocket  
anyhow | Integrate with [``anyhow``](https://lib.rs/crates/anyhow) crate.  
eyre06 | Integrate with version 0.6.x of the [``eyre``](https://lib.rs/crates/eyre) crate.  
i18n | Support for internationalization  
acme-native-roots | Support for ACME(Automatic Certificate Management Environment)  
acme-webpki-roots | Support for ACME using webpki TLS roots rather than native TLS roots  
tokio-metrics | Integrate with [``tokio-metrics``](https://lib.rs/crates/tokio-metrics) crate.  
embed | Integrate with [``rust-embed``](https://lib.rs/crates/rust-embed) crate.  
xml | Integrate with [``quick-xml``](https://lib.rs/crates/quick-xml) crate.  
yaml | Integrate with [``serde-yaml``](https://lib.rs/crates/serde-yaml) crate.  
requestid | Associates an unique ID with each incoming request  
sonic-rs | Uses [``sonic-rs``](https://github.com/cloudwego/sonic-rs) instead of ``serde_json``. Pls, checkout ``sonic-rs`` requirements to properly enable ``sonic-rs`` capabilities  
## Safety
This crate uses ````#!``[``forbid```(```unsafe_code```)```]```` to ensure everything is implemented in 100% Safe Rust.

# Poem Framework
 ![Crates.io version⟨4⟩ ](https://crates.io/crates/poem)  ![Download⟨5⟩ ](https://crates.io/crates/poem)  ![docs.rs docs⟨6⟩ ](https://docs.rs/poem)  ![Unsafe Rust forbidden⟨7⟩ ](https://github.com/rust-secure-code/safety-dance/) ![rustc 1.85.0+⟨8⟩]  ![⟨9⟩ ](https://discord.gg/qWWNxwasb7)
``A program is like a poem`,` you cannot write a poem without writing it`.` `-``-``-` Dijkstra``
A full-featured and easy-to-use web framework with the Rust programming language.
  * Docs⟨10⟩
  * Cargo package⟨11⟩


## Features
  * Both _Ease_ of use and performance.
  * Minimizing the use of generics.
  * Blazing fast and flexible routing.
  * ```tower`::``Service`` and ```tower`::``Layer`` compatibility.
  * Use poem-openapi⟨12⟩ to write APIs that comply with OAS3⟨13⟩ specifications and automatically generate documents.


## Crate features
To avoid compiling unused dependencies, Poem gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:
Feature | Description  
---|---  
server | Server and listener APIs (enabled by default)  
compression | Support decompress request body and compress response body  
cookie | Support for Cookie  
csrf | Support for Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) protection  
multipart | Support for Multipart  
native-tls | Support for HTTP server over TLS with ``native-tls``⟨14⟩  
openssl-tls | Support for HTTP server over TLS with ``openssl-tls``⟨15⟩  
opentelemetry | Support for opentelemetry  
prometheus | Support for Prometheus  
redis-session | Support for RedisSession  
rustls | Support for HTTP server over TLS with ``rustls``⟨16⟩  
session | Support for session  
sse | Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
static-files | Support static files endpoint  
tempfile | Support for ``tempfile``⟨17⟩  
tower-compat | Adapters for ```tower`::``Layer`` and ```tower`::``Service``.  
websocket | Support for WebSocket  
anyhow | Integrate with ``anyhow``⟨18⟩ crate.  
eyre06 | Integrate with version 0.6.x of the ``eyre``⟨19⟩ crate.  
i18n | Support for internationalization  
acme-native-roots | Support for ACME(Automatic Certificate Management Environment)  
acme-webpki-roots | Support for ACME using webpki TLS roots rather than native TLS roots  
tokio-metrics | Integrate with ``tokio-metrics``⟨20⟩ crate.  
embed | Integrate with ``rust-embed``⟨21⟩ crate.  
xml | Integrate with ``quick-xml``⟨22⟩ crate.  
yaml | Integrate with ``serde-yaml``⟨23⟩ crate.  
requestid | Associates an unique ID with each incoming request  
sonic-rs | Uses ``sonic-rs``⟨24⟩ instead of ``serde_json``. Pls, checkout ``sonic-rs`` requirements to properly enable ``sonic-rs`` capabilities  
## Safety
This crate uses ````#!``[``forbid```(```unsafe_code```)```]```` to ensure everything is implemented in 100% Safe Rust.
## Example
```
``use` `poem`::````{`get`,` handler`,` `listener`::``TcpListener`,` `web`::``Path`,` Route`,` Server```}```;`
``#``[``handler``]``
``fn` `hello`````(`Path`(``name``)`: `Path`<``String``>`````)```` ``->` String` ````{`
  `format!``(```"`hello: `{}``"```,` name`)`
```}```
``#``[``tokio`::`main``]``
async ``fn` `main`````(````)```` ``->` ``Result``<``(``)`, `std`::```io`::``Error`>``` ````{`
  `let` app `=` `Route`::``new`(``)``.``at``(```"`/hello/:name`"```,` `get``(`hello`)``)``;`
  `Server`::``new`(``TcpListener`::``bind`(```"`0.0.0.0:3000`"```)``)`
   `.``run``(`app`)`
   `.`await
```}```
`
```

More examples can be found here⟨25⟩.
## MSRV
The minimum supported Rust version for this crate is ```1.``85``.``0```.

# Crate poemCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/src/poem/lib.rs.html#1-311)
Expand description
Poem is a full-featured and easy-to-use web framework with the Rust programming language.
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#table-of-contents)Table of contents
  * [Quickstart](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#quickstart)
  * [Endpoint](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#endpoint)
  * [Extractors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#extractors)
  * [Routing](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#routing)
  * [Responses](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#responses)
  * [Handling errors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#handling-errors)
  * [Middleware](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#middleware)
  * [Crate features](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#crate-features)


## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#quickstart)Quickstart
```
use poem::{IntoResponse, Route, Server, get, handler, listener::TcpListener, web::Path};
#[handler]
fn hello(Path(name): Path<String>) -> String {
  format!("hello: {}", name)
}
#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), std::io::Error> {
  let app = Route::new().at("/hello/:name", get(hello));
  Server::new(TcpListener::bind("0.0.0.0:3000"))
    .run(app)
    .await
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#endpoint)Endpoint
The [`Endpoint`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint") trait represents a type that can handle HTTP requests, and it returns the `Result<T: IntoResponse, Error>` type.
The [`handler`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/attr.handler.html "attr poem::handler") macro is used to convert a function into an endpoint.
```
use poem::{
  Endpoint, Request, Result, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  test::TestClient,
};
#[handler]
fn return_str() -> &'static str {
  "hello"
}
#[handler]
fn return_err() -> Result<&'static str, NotFoundError> {
  Err(NotFoundError)
}
let resp = TestClient::new(return_str).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status_is_ok();
resp.assert_text("hello").await;
let resp = TestClient::new(return_err).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND);
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#extractors)Extractors
The extractor is used to extract something from the HTTP request.
`Poem` provides some [commonly used extractors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest") for extracting something from HTTP requests.
In the following example, the `index` function uses 3 extractors to extract the remote address, HTTP method and URI.
```
use poem::{
  handler,
  http::{Method, Uri},
  web::RemoteAddr,
};
#[handler]
fn index(remote_addr: &RemoteAddr, method: Method, uri: &Uri) {}
```

By default, the extractor will return a `400 Bad Request` when an error occurs, but sometimes you may want to change this behavior, so you can handle the error yourself.
In the following example, when the [`Query`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/struct.Query.html "struct poem::web::Query") extractor fails, it will return a `500 Internal Server` response and the reason for the error.
```
use poem::{
  IntoResponse, Response, Result, error::ParseQueryError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  web::Query,
};
use serde::Deserialize;
#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
struct Params {
  name: String,
}
#[handler]
fn index(res: Result<Query<Params>>) -> Result<impl IntoResponse> {
  match res {
    Ok(Query(params)) => Ok(params.name.into_response()),
    Err(err) if err.is::<ParseQueryError>() => Ok(Response::builder()
      .status(StatusCode::INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)
      .body(err.to_string())),
    Err(err) => Err(err),
  }
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#routing)Routing
There are three available routes.
  * [`Route`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Route.html "struct poem::Route") Routing for path
  * [`RouteDomain`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteDomain.html "struct poem::RouteDomain") Routing for domain
  * [`RouteMethod`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteMethod.html "struct poem::RouteMethod") Routing for HTTP method


```
use poem::{Route, get, handler, post, web::Path};
#[handler]
async fn get_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn delete_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn create_user() {}
let app = Route::new()
  .at("/user/:id", get(get_user).delete(delete_user))
  .at("/user", post(create_user));
```

You can create custom extractors, see also [`FromRequest`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest").
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#responses)Responses
All types that can be converted to HTTP response [`Response`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Response.html "struct poem::Response") should implement [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse").
In the following example, the `string_response` and `status_response` functions return the `String` and `StatusCode` types, because `Poem` has implemented the [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse") trait for them.
The `no_response` function does not return a value. We can think that its return type is `()`, and `Poem` also implements [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse") for `()`, which is always converted to `200 OK`.
The `result_response` function returns a `Result` type, which means that an error may occur.
```
use poem::{Result, handler, http::StatusCode};
#[handler]
fn string_response() -> String {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn status_response() -> StatusCode {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn no_response() {}
#[handler]
fn result_response() -> Result<String> {
  todo!()
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#handling-errors)Handling errors
The following example returns customized content when [`NotFoundError`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/error/struct.NotFoundError.html "struct poem::error::NotFoundError") occurs.
```
use poem::{
  EndpointExt, IntoResponse, Response, Route, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
};
#[handler]
fn foo() {}
#[handler]
fn bar() {}
let app =
  Route::new()
    .at("/foo", foo)
    .at("/bar", bar)
    .catch_error(|err: NotFoundError| async move {
      Response::builder()
        .status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND)
        .body("custom not found")
    });
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#middleware)Middleware
You can call the [`with`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.EndpointExt.html#method.with "method poem::endpoint::EndpointExt::with") method on the [`Endpoint`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint") to apply a middleware to an endpoint. It actually converts the original endpoint to a new endpoint.
```
use poem::{EndpointExt, Route, handler, middleware::Tracing};
#[handler]
fn index() {}
let app = Route::new().at("/", index).with(Tracing);
```

You can create your own middleware, see also [`Middleware`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/middleware/trait.Middleware.html "trait poem::middleware::Middleware").
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#crate-features)Crate features
To avoid compiling unused dependencies, `Poem` gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:
Feature| Description  
---|---  
server| Server and listener APIs(enable by default)  
compression| Support decompress request body and compress response body  
cookie| Support for Cookie  
csrf| Support for Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) protection  
multipart| Support for Multipart  
native-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`native-tls`](https://crates.io/crates/native-tls)  
openssl-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`openssl-tls`](https://crates.io/crates/openssl)  
opentelemetry| Support for opentelemetry  
prometheus| Support for Prometheus  
redis-session| Support for RedisSession  
rustls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`rustls`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls)  
session| Support for session  
sse| Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
tempfile| Support for [`tempfile`](https://crates.io/crates/tempfile)  
test| Test utilities to test your endpoints.  
tower-compat| Adapters for `tower::Layer` and `tower::Service`.  
websocket| Support for WebSocket  
anyhow| Integrate with the [`anyhow`](https://crates.io/crates/anyhow) crate.  
eyre06| Integrate with version 0.6.x of the [`eyre`](https://crates.io/crates/eyre) crate.  
i18n| Support for internationalization  
acme-native-roots| Support for ACME(Automatic Certificate Management Environment)  
acme-webpki-roots| Support for ACME using webpki TLS roots rather than native TLS roots  
tokio-metrics| Integrate with the [`tokio-metrics`](https://crates.io/crates/tokio-metrics) crate.  
embed| Integrate with [`rust-embed`](https://crates.io/crates/rust-embed) crate.  
xml| Integrate with [`quick-xml`](https://crates.io/crates/quick-xml) crate.  
yaml| Integrate with [`serde-yaml`](https://crates.io/crates/serde-yaml) crate.  
sonic-rs| Uses [`sonic-rs`](https://github.com/cloudwego/sonic-rs) instead of `serde_json`. Pls, checkout `sonic-rs` requirements to properly enable `sonic-rs` capabilities

[](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate poemCopy item path
Settings⟨1⟩
Help⟨2⟩
SummarySource⟨3⟩
Expand description
Poem is a full-featured and easy-to-use web framework with the Rust programming language.
## §⟨4⟩Table of contents
  * Quickstart⟨5⟩
  * Endpoint⟨6⟩
  * Extractors⟨7⟩
  * Routing⟨8⟩
  * Responses⟨9⟩
  * Handling errors⟨10⟩
  * Middleware⟨11⟩
  * Crate features⟨12⟩


## §⟨5⟩Quickstart
```
use poem::{IntoResponse, Route, Server, get, handler, listener::TcpListener, web::Path};
#[handler]
fn hello(Path(name): Path<String>) -> String {
  format!("hello: {}", name)
}
#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), std::io::Error> {
  let app = Route::new().at("/hello/:name", get(hello));
  Server::new(TcpListener::bind("0.0.0.0:3000"))
    .run(app)
    .await
}
```

## §⟨6⟩Endpoint
The `Endpoint`⟨13⟩ trait represents a type that can handle HTTP requests, and it returns the `Result<T: IntoResponse, Error>` type.
The `handler`⟨14⟩ macro is used to convert a function into an endpoint.
```
use poem::{
  Endpoint, Request, Result, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  test::TestClient,
};
#[handler]
fn return_str() -> &'static str {
  "hello"
}
#[handler]
fn return_err() -> Result<&'static str, NotFoundError> {
  Err(NotFoundError)
}
let resp = TestClient::new(return_str).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status_is_ok();
resp.assert_text("hello").await;
let resp = TestClient::new(return_err).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND);
```

## §⟨7⟩Extractors
The extractor is used to extract something from the HTTP request.
`Poem` provides some commonly used extractors⟨15⟩ for extracting something from HTTP requests.
In the following example, the `index` function uses 3 extractors to extract the remote address, HTTP method and URI.
```
use poem::{
  handler,
  http::{Method, Uri},
  web::RemoteAddr,
};
#[handler]
fn index(remote_addr: &RemoteAddr, method: Method, uri: &Uri) {}
```

By default, the extractor will return a `400 Bad Request` when an error occurs, but sometimes you may want to change this behavior, so you can handle the error yourself.
In the following example, when the `Query`⟨16⟩ extractor fails, it will return a `500 Internal Server` response and the reason for the error.
```
use poem::{
  IntoResponse, Response, Result, error::ParseQueryError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  web::Query,
};
use serde::Deserialize;
#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
struct Params {
  name: String,
}
#[handler]
fn index(res: Result<Query<Params>>) -> Result<impl IntoResponse> {
  match res {
    Ok(Query(params)) => Ok(params.name.into_response()),
    Err(err) if err.is::<ParseQueryError>() => Ok(Response::builder()
      .status(StatusCode::INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)
      .body(err.to_string())),
    Err(err) => Err(err),
  }
}
```

## §⟨8⟩Routing
There are three available routes.
  * `Route`⟨17⟩ Routing for path
  * `RouteDomain`⟨18⟩ Routing for domain
  * `RouteMethod`⟨19⟩ Routing for HTTP method


```
use poem::{Route, get, handler, post, web::Path};
#[handler]
async fn get_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn delete_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn create_user() {}
let app = Route::new()
  .at("/user/:id", get(get_user).delete(delete_user))
  .at("/user", post(create_user));
```

You can create custom extractors, see also `FromRequest`⟨15⟩.
## §⟨9⟩Responses
All types that can be converted to HTTP response `Response`⟨20⟩ should implement `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩.
In the following example, the `string_response` and `status_response` functions return the `String` and `StatusCode` types, because `Poem` has implemented the `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩ trait for them.
The `no_response` function does not return a value. We can think that its return type is `()`, and `Poem` also implements `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩ for `()`, which is always converted to `200 OK`.
The `result_response` function returns a `Result` type, which means that an error may occur.
```
use poem::{Result, handler, http::StatusCode};
#[handler]
fn string_response() -> String {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn status_response() -> StatusCode {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn no_response() {}
#[handler]
fn result_response() -> Result<String> {
  todo!()
}
```

## §⟨10⟩Handling errors
The following example returns customized content when `NotFoundError`⟨22⟩ occurs.
```
use poem::{
  EndpointExt, IntoResponse, Response, Route, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
};
#[handler]
fn foo() {}
#[handler]
fn bar() {}
let app =
  Route::new()
    .at("/foo", foo)
    .at("/bar", bar)
    .catch_error(|err: NotFoundError| async move {
      Response::builder()
        .status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND)
        .body("custom not found")
    });
```

## §⟨11⟩Middleware
You can call the `with`⟨23⟩ method on the `Endpoint`⟨13⟩ to apply a middleware to an endpoint. It actually converts the original endpoint to a new endpoint.
```
use poem::{EndpointExt, Route, handler, middleware::Tracing};
#[handler]
fn index() {}
let app = Route::new().at("/", index).with(Tracing);
```

You can create your own middleware, see also `Middleware`⟨24⟩.
## §⟨12⟩Crate features
To avoid compiling unused dependencies, `Poem` gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:
Feature| Description  
---|---  
server| Server and listener APIs(enable by default)  
compression| Support decompress request body and compress response body  
cookie| Support for Cookie  
csrf| Support for Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) protection  
multipart| Support for Multipart  
native-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with `native-tls`⟨25⟩  
openssl-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with `openssl-tls`⟨26⟩  
opentelemetry| Support for opentelemetry  
prometheus| Support for Prometheus  
redis-session| Support for RedisSession  
rustls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with `rustls`⟨27⟩  
session| Support for session  
sse| Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
tempfile| Support for `tempfile`⟨28⟩  
test| Test utilities to test your endpoints.  
tower-compat| Adapters for `tower::Layer` and `tower::Service`.  
websocket| Support for WebSocket  
anyhow| Integrate with the `anyhow`⟨29⟩ crate.  
eyre06| Integrate with version 0.6.x of the `eyre`⟨30⟩ crate.  
i18n| Support for internationalization  
acme-native-roots| Support for ACME(Automatic Certificate Management Environment)  
acme-webpki-roots| Support for ACME using webpki TLS roots rather than native TLS roots  
tokio-metrics| Integrate with the `tokio-metrics`⟨31⟩ crate.  
embed| Integrate with `rust-embed`⟨32⟩ crate.  
xml| Integrate with `quick-xml`⟨33⟩ crate.  
yaml| Integrate with `serde-yaml`⟨34⟩ crate.  
sonic-rs| Uses `sonic-rs`⟨35⟩ instead of `serde_json`. Pls, checkout `sonic-rs` requirements to properly enable `sonic-rs` capabilities

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#quickstart)Quickstart
```
use poem::{IntoResponse, Route, Server, get, handler, listener::TcpListener, web::Path};
#[handler]
fn hello(Path(name): Path<String>) -> String {
  format!("hello: {}", name)
}
#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), std::io::Error> {
  let app = Route::new().at("/hello/:name", get(hello));
  Server::new(TcpListener::bind("0.0.0.0:3000"))
    .run(app)
    .await
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#endpoint)Endpoint
The [`Endpoint`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint") trait represents a type that can handle HTTP requests, and it returns the `Result<T: IntoResponse, Error>` type.
The [`handler`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/attr.handler.html "attr poem::handler") macro is used to convert a function into an endpoint.
```
use poem::{
  Endpoint, Request, Result, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  test::TestClient,
};
#[handler]
fn return_str() -> &'static str {
  "hello"
}
#[handler]
fn return_err() -> Result<&'static str, NotFoundError> {
  Err(NotFoundError)
}
let resp = TestClient::new(return_str).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status_is_ok();
resp.assert_text("hello").await;
let resp = TestClient::new(return_err).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND);
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#extractors)Extractors
The extractor is used to extract something from the HTTP request.
`Poem` provides some [commonly used extractors](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest") for extracting something from HTTP requests.
In the following example, the `index` function uses 3 extractors to extract the remote address, HTTP method and URI.
```
use poem::{
  handler,
  http::{Method, Uri},
  web::RemoteAddr,
};
#[handler]
fn index(remote_addr: &RemoteAddr, method: Method, uri: &Uri) {}
```

By default, the extractor will return a `400 Bad Request` when an error occurs, but sometimes you may want to change this behavior, so you can handle the error yourself.
In the following example, when the [`Query`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/struct.Query.html "struct poem::web::Query") extractor fails, it will return a `500 Internal Server` response and the reason for the error.
```
use poem::{
  IntoResponse, Response, Result, error::ParseQueryError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  web::Query,
};
use serde::Deserialize;
#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
struct Params {
  name: String,
}
#[handler]
fn index(res: Result<Query<Params>>) -> Result<impl IntoResponse> {
  match res {
    Ok(Query(params)) => Ok(params.name.into_response()),
    Err(err) if err.is::<ParseQueryError>() => Ok(Response::builder()
      .status(StatusCode::INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)
      .body(err.to_string())),
    Err(err) => Err(err),
  }
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#routing)Routing
There are three available routes.
  * [`Route`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Route.html "struct poem::Route") Routing for path
  * [`RouteDomain`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteDomain.html "struct poem::RouteDomain") Routing for domain
  * [`RouteMethod`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.RouteMethod.html "struct poem::RouteMethod") Routing for HTTP method


```
use poem::{Route, get, handler, post, web::Path};
#[handler]
async fn get_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn delete_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn create_user() {}
let app = Route::new()
  .at("/user/:id", get(get_user).delete(delete_user))
  .at("/user", post(create_user));
```

You can create custom extractors, see also [`FromRequest`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.FromRequest.html "trait poem::web::FromRequest").
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#responses)Responses
All types that can be converted to HTTP response [`Response`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/struct.Response.html "struct poem::Response") should implement [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse").
In the following example, the `string_response` and `status_response` functions return the `String` and `StatusCode` types, because `Poem` has implemented the [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse") trait for them.
The `no_response` function does not return a value. We can think that its return type is `()`, and `Poem` also implements [`IntoResponse`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/web/trait.IntoResponse.html "trait poem::web::IntoResponse") for `()`, which is always converted to `200 OK`.
The `result_response` function returns a `Result` type, which means that an error may occur.
```
use poem::{Result, handler, http::StatusCode};
#[handler]
fn string_response() -> String {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn status_response() -> StatusCode {
  todo!()
}
#[handler]
fn no_response() {}
#[handler]
fn result_response() -> Result<String> {
  todo!()
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#handling-errors)Handling errors
The following example returns customized content when [`NotFoundError`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/error/struct.NotFoundError.html "struct poem::error::NotFoundError") occurs.
```
use poem::{
  EndpointExt, IntoResponse, Response, Route, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
};
#[handler]
fn foo() {}
#[handler]
fn bar() {}
let app =
  Route::new()
    .at("/foo", foo)
    .at("/bar", bar)
    .catch_error(|err: NotFoundError| async move {
      Response::builder()
        .status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND)
        .body("custom not found")
    });
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#middleware)Middleware
You can call the [`with`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.EndpointExt.html#method.with "method poem::endpoint::EndpointExt::with") method on the [`Endpoint`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/endpoint/trait.Endpoint.html "trait poem::endpoint::Endpoint") to apply a middleware to an endpoint. It actually converts the original endpoint to a new endpoint.
```
use poem::{EndpointExt, Route, handler, middleware::Tracing};
#[handler]
fn index() {}
let app = Route::new().at("/", index).with(Tracing);
```

You can create your own middleware, see also [`Middleware`](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/middleware/trait.Middleware.html "trait poem::middleware::Middleware").
## [§](https://docs.rs/poem/latest/poem/#crate-features)Crate features
To avoid compiling unused dependencies, `Poem` gates certain features, all of which are disabled by default:
Feature| Description  
---|---  
server| Server and listener APIs(enable by default)  
compression| Support decompress request body and compress response body  
cookie| Support for Cookie  
csrf| Support for Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) protection  
multipart| Support for Multipart  
native-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`native-tls`](https://crates.io/crates/native-tls)  
openssl-tls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`openssl-tls`](https://crates.io/crates/openssl)  
opentelemetry| Support for opentelemetry  
prometheus| Support for Prometheus  
redis-session| Support for RedisSession  
rustls| Support for HTTP server over TLS with [`rustls`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls)  
session| Support for session  
sse| Support Server-Sent Events (SSE)  
tempfile| Support for [`tempfile`](https://crates.io/crates/tempfile)  
test| Test utilities to test your endpoints.  
tower-compat| Adapters for `tower::Layer` and `tower::Service`.  
websocket| Support for WebSocket  
anyhow| Integrate with the [`anyhow`](https://crates.io/crates/anyhow) crate.  
eyre06| Integrate with version 0.6.x of the [`eyre`](https://crates.io/crates/eyre) crate.  
i18n| Support for internationalization  
acme-native-roots| Support for ACME(Automatic Certificate Management Environment)  
acme-webpki-roots| Support for ACME using webpki TLS roots rather than native TLS roots  
tokio-metrics| Integrate with the [`tokio-metrics`](https://crates.io/crates/tokio-metrics) crate.  
embed| Integrate with [`rust-embed`](https://crates.io/crates/rust-embed) crate.  
xml| Integrate with [`quick-xml`](https://crates.io/crates/quick-xml) crate.  
yaml| Integrate with [`serde-yaml`](https://crates.io/crates/serde-yaml) crate.  
sonic-rs| Uses [`sonic-rs`](https://github.com/cloudwego/sonic-rs) instead of `serde_json`. Pls, checkout `sonic-rs` requirements to properly enable `sonic-rs` capabilities

## §⟨6⟩Endpoint
The `Endpoint`⟨13⟩ trait represents a type that can handle HTTP requests, and it returns the `Result<T: IntoResponse, Error>` type.
The `handler`⟨14⟩ macro is used to convert a function into an endpoint.
```
use poem::{
  Endpoint, Request, Result, error::NotFoundError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  test::TestClient,
};
#[handler]
fn return_str() -> &'static str {
  "hello"
}
#[handler]
fn return_err() -> Result<&'static str, NotFoundError> {
  Err(NotFoundError)
}
let resp = TestClient::new(return_str).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status_is_ok();
resp.assert_text("hello").await;
let resp = TestClient::new(return_err).get("/").send().await;
resp.assert_status(StatusCode::NOT_FOUND);
```

## §⟨7⟩Extractors
The extractor is used to extract something from the HTTP request.
`Poem` provides some commonly used extractors⟨15⟩ for extracting something from HTTP requests.
In the following example, the `index` function uses 3 extractors to extract the remote address, HTTP method and URI.
```
use poem::{
  handler,
  http::{Method, Uri},
  web::RemoteAddr,
};
#[handler]
fn index(remote_addr: &RemoteAddr, method: Method, uri: &Uri) {}
```

By default, the extractor will return a `400 Bad Request` when an error occurs, but sometimes you may want to change this behavior, so you can handle the error yourself.
In the following example, when the `Query`⟨16⟩ extractor fails, it will return a `500 Internal Server` response and the reason for the error.
```
use poem::{
  IntoResponse, Response, Result, error::ParseQueryError, handler, http::StatusCode,
  web::Query,
};
use serde::Deserialize;
#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
struct Params {
  name: String,
}
#[handler]
fn index(res: Result<Query<Params>>) -> Result<impl IntoResponse> {
  match res {
    Ok(Query(params)) => Ok(params.name.into_response()),
    Err(err) if err.is::<ParseQueryError>() => Ok(Response::builder()
      .status(StatusCode::INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)
      .body(err.to_string())),
    Err(err) => Err(err),
  }
}
```

## §⟨8⟩Routing
There are three available routes.
  * `Route`⟨17⟩ Routing for path
  * `RouteDomain`⟨18⟩ Routing for domain
  * `RouteMethod`⟨19⟩ Routing for HTTP method


```
use poem::{Route, get, handler, post, web::Path};
#[handler]
async fn get_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn delete_user(id: Path<String>) {}
#[handler]
async fn create_user() {}
let app = Route::new()
  .at("/user/:id", get(get_user).delete(delete_user))
  .at("/user", post(create_user));
```

You can create custom extractors, see also `FromRequest`⟨15⟩.

The `no_response` function does not return a value. We can think that its return type is `()`, and `Poem` also implements `IntoResponse`⟨21⟩ for `()`, which is always converted to `200 OK`.
The `result_response` function returns a `Result` type, which means that an error may occur.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `poem` crate is a full-featured, user-friendly web framework for building HTTP services in Rust. It offers robust capabilities such as routing (path, domain, and method-based), request extractors, customizable error handling, middleware support, and seamless response conversion via the `IntoResponse` trait. Additionally, it simplifies endpoint creation with the `handler` macro and supports extensibility through custom extractors and middleware.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Routing Capabilities  
✅ **Factual**: The `poem` crate supports routing based on paths, domains, and HTTP methods using constructs like `Route`, `RouteDomain`, and `RouteMethod`.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `poem` crate only supports routing based on HTTP methods and does not provide constructs for path-based or domain-based routing.  

---

### Pair 2: Extractors for HTTP Requests  
✅ **Factual**: The `poem` crate provides built-in extractors, such as `RemoteAddr`, `Method`, and `Uri`, to extract data from HTTP requests, and allows custom extractors to be implemented using the `FromRequest` trait.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `poem` crate does not support custom extractors and only provides a fixed set of built-in extractors for HTTP requests.  

---

### Pair 3: Error Handling in Extractors  
✅ **Factual**: When an extractor fails, the `poem` crate defaults to returning a `400 Bad Request` response, but developers can override this behavior to return custom error responses, such as `500 Internal Server Error`.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `poem` crate automatically retries failed extractors multiple times before returning a `400 Bad Request` response, and this behavior cannot be customized.
